Neuro-genetic machine learning framework accelerates the optimization of Ag/MnOx catalyst for total oxidation of toluene Jiaqian Yang Conceptualization Investigation Software Writing - original draft Zhiping Ye Conceptualization Methodology Writing - review & editing Guanjie Wang Software Visualization Liang Zhao Data curation Formal analysis Xiuwen Zhang Validation Formal analysis Jiade Wang Resources Supervision Writing - review & editing * Yufan Jin Visualization Validation College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, 310014, PR China College of Environment Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 PR China College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A neuro-genetic machine learning framework (ANN-GA) was employed to optimize and predict the optimum preparation parameters for the precipitation synthesis of high-efficiency silver-doped manganese oxides (Ag/MnOx) for toluene total oxidation. The preparation conditions of Ag/MnOx for maximum CO2 yield were predicted to be at 13.2 wt% of silver loading, 41.5 min of stirring time, 461 ℃ of calcination temperature, and 4.3 h of calcination time. The resulting Ag/MnOx-GA catalyst achieved the lowest T50 (CO2) of 206 ℃ comparing to the catalyst suggested by the response surface methodology (RSM) (214 ℃) and synthesized catalyst Ag/MnOx-R16 (220 ℃). The obtained relative importance of each factor involved in the preparation process revealed that all of the parameters should be taken into account, among which the silver loading had the most significant impact on the catalytic reactivity. The synthesized materials were characterized by ICP-OES, SEM/EDS, BET, Raman, XRD, XPS, TGA, H2-TPR, and O2-TPD. The results indicated that the Ag/MnOx-GA exhibited the largest surface area (84.4), the lowest average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn (3.25), the best redox capacity, and the highest ratios of Oads/Olatt (0.75). These consequences provided evidence that the toluene total oxidation was more likely to occur on the surface of Ag/MnOx-GA at a relatively lower temperature. Keywords Machine learning Genetic algorithm Catalyst optimization Manganese oxide Volatile organic compounds Catalytic oxidation 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation has been regarded as one of the most promising and efficient alternatives among the volatile organic compounds (VOCs) elimination strategies [1]. Manganese oxides (MnOx), especially silver-doped manganese oxides (Ag/MnOx), have attracted most of the research focus due to their considerable potential for the VOCs total oxidation. It is widely accepted that silver can adsorb and activate gas-phase oxygen [2,3], and K+ in the structure of MnOx can be replaced by silver (for example, Ag+ can substitute K+ in the tunnels of cryptomelane-type octahedral molecular sieve) [4]. These features have been proven to enhance the labile surface oxygen reactivity and tune the catalytic activity of MnOx catalyst toward VOCs. To the best of our knowledge, for most metal oxide catalysts, the preparation technique [5,6], metal loading [7,8], active components determination, and proportion [9,10] are proved to affect the catalytic oxidation efficiency and product selectivity largely. In terms of Ag/MnOx, the important catalyst properties such as the form of silver [11,12], the presence of structural defects [13], the combination of manganese and silver [14], the pore structure, and the physical morphology of the material [15,16] are largely determined by the multivariate preparation processes. The variables involved in these processes depend on preparation methods. For the precipitation synthesis investigated in this work, there are four crucial variables, including silver loading [17,18], stirring time [12], calcination temperature [19,20], and calcination time [21], that have significant impacts on catalyst activity. The fact that catalytic performance is affected by multiple factors involved in the preparation process at the same time makes it necessary to control all the conditions simultaneously. Hence, the conclusions obtained from conditional experiments on one or several influencing factors under hypothetical conditions could be inadequate and incomplete [6,11,22]. For instance, Deng et al. investigated the effects of doping silver concentration in Ag incorporated cryptomelane-type manganese oxide (Ag-OMS-2) on the catalytic performance for benzene degradation. The result suggested that the catalyst with an Mn/Ag mole ratio of 40 exhibited the highest reactivity [14]. However, the catalysts with different Mn/Ag mole ratios were all prepared in the same calcination temperature of 500 ℃, which was considered another important factor that markedly affected the catalyst performance. According to the study carried out by Wu et al. [20], the MnOx sample calcined at 400 °C was proved to have the highest catalytic activity. Therefore, all of the important influence factors should be taken into account as the correlation between the preparation conditions and catalytic performance is multivariate, nonlinear, and dynamic. Generally, the traditional single-factor experiments are difficult to fully reflect the impacts on reaction efficiency when multiple influence factors varying simultaneously. Besides, applying the exhaustive method based on the combinations of the independent variables within small intervals means that a large number of tests are required, which is definitively uneconomical and inefficient. For tackling these challenges, machine learning (ML) provides a set of effective and economical techniques that facilitate the high-dimensional data sets analysis and the predictive model development based on such data sets [23,24]. As described in some excellent up-to-date reviews [25–27], ML techniques have not only been applied to accelerate the screening of different catalyst formulations [28,29], optimize the processing efficiencies of reaction systems [30,31], and uncover likely reaction mechanisms [32], but also been confirmed to be promising tools for exploring potential catalysts with desired performances [23,33]. For instance, a holistic ML framework trained by the existing data of ∼1000 idealized alloy surfaces with their adsorption and electronic properties was proposed to accelerate the process of bimetallic catalyst discovery [34]. The developed feedforward artificial neural network (ANN) was verified to identify most of the known alloy catalysts for methanol electro-oxidation and also suggested prospective metal additives such as Fe, Co, and Ni for bimetallic catalysts with declined overpotentials. Nandy et al. performed an uncertainty-aware evolutionary optimization using an ANN coupled with genetic algorithm (GA) to search a >37000 candidate catalysts, both favorable (for oxidatively stable complexes) and unfavorable (for oxidatively unstable complexes) oxo formation energies were identified [35]. As a promising global optimization model, ANN-GA can explore the whole candidate catalyst space to reveal potential catalytic materials even when fewer data sets are available for training [36–39]. Although most studies did obtain optimum results through ML simulations and predictions, these results were usually supported by model validation indicators or catalyst performance, the reliability of the consequences was not further verified from the perspective of physicochemical properties and structure-activity relationship of catalysts. For example, Soleimanzadeh et al. investigated the impacts of the catalyst preparation variables on the NO conversion for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3, and a V loading of 0.0051 mol, a calcination temperature of 491 ℃ and an impregnation temperature of 50 ℃ for the optimum V2O5/TiO2 nanocatalysts were predicted by the developed feedforward back-propagation neural network [40]. In fact, a lot of studies have come up with their best experimental conditions or preparation variables according to the proposed ML models [40–44]. Nevertheless, few evidences were provided by these publications to prove the effectiveness of the black-box model in the rapid screening and optimization of various catalysts except for the prediction accuracies of the test subsets and the performance evaluation consequences. Herein, this work was undertaken to advance the current knowledge on discovering high-performance Ag/MnOx catalysts with the aid of an ANN-GA framework, and more importantly, to probe the feasibility and reliability of the ML models on optimizing catalyst preparation conditions. To simplify the data acquisition process, a central composite design (CCD) based on critical conditions of the catalyst preparation process was performed for experimental design. We applied an ML framework consisting of a feedforward ANN and a GA optimizer for searching potential Ag/MnOx catalysts as well as the corresponding preparation conditions from a virtual catalyst space. The catalytic performance of the predicted optimum Ag/MnOx catalyst for gaseous toluene abatement was investigated. The comparative outcomes of the catalyst suggested by ANN-GA and RSM were analyzed. The resultant impacts on the textural property, oxygen species reactivity, redox capacity, and catalytic activity were revealed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ag/MnOx catalysts were synthesized by precipitation method under acidic conditions. 3.16 g KMnO4 (Fluka, 99 %) was dissolved in 80 mL of distilled water and heated to 60 ℃. Then the solution was added to an aqueous acidified solution consists of 100 mL of a 0.24 mol/L acetic acid (CH3COOH; Sigma–Aldrich, 99 %), 7.53 g Mn nitrate precursors (Mn(NO3)2·4H2O; Fisher Scientific, 99 %) and a certain amount (according to different Ag loadings) of AgNO3 (Sigma–Aldrich, 99 %) to get a precipitate. Then the suspension was vigorously stirred and an additional amount (based on different stirring time) of 2 mol/L acetic acid was added drop-wise to the suspension to retrieve the volatilized acetic acid. The neutral sample was obtained after centrifugation and washing with deionized water for several times. The resultant product was dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h and then calcinated at 200–600 ℃ for 2−6 h according to the experimental design matrix of CCD. 2.2 Catalyst characterization A surface area and porosity analyzer (Autosorb-iQ-2MP) was employed to get the nitrogen adsorption-desorption curves at –196 ℃. Prior to measurement, the solids were outgassed under primary vacuum for 3 h at 300 ℃. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was applied to calculate the specific surface area (SBET) of the materials. And the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was employed to determine the pore diameter (Dp) distribution and the porous volume (Vp) from the desorption branches of the isotherms. Elemental analysis of Mn, Ag, and K was performed through inductively coupled plasma/optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 720ES). Prior to analysis, all samples were treated with aqua regia solution. Crystal structure study of the synthesized catalysts was carried out using a Rigaku D/MAX-RB diffractometer (Cu Kα X-ray radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å). The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were scanned in the 2θ range 10–80°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements of the as-prepared samples were carried out with a VG Multilab2000 spectrometer, using Al Kα radiation (λ = 1486.6 eV) as the radiation source. Peak fitting was processed with AVANTAGE software. Raman spectra were recorded on a Raman microprobe (LabRAM HR Evolution) fitted with an Ar+-ion laser (532 nm) with ±1.5 cm−1 spectral resolution. Scanning electron microscopy plus energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM/EDS) results were obtained using a Zeiss (SUPRA55 VP) after precoating the samples with gold (ion sputtering instrument, JFC-1600). The H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed by using a PCA-1200 multifunction adsorption apparatus. 0.1 g of sample was pretreated under Ar flow at 200 ℃ for 1 h to remove the surface weakly adsorbed molecules. After cooling down to room temperature, a 10 % H2/Ar flow with a 50 mL/min flow rate was introduced to the reactor. The temperature was ramped to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min. Temperature-programmed desorptions of O2 (O2-TPD) measurements were carried out on the same instrument. 50 mg of the sample was heated at 200 ℃ under Ar flow for 1 h. Then the catalyst was cooled down to room temperature, and a 10 % O2/Ar flow was introduced to the reactor at a 50 mL/min flow rate for 1 h before desorption. Subsequently, the desorption experiment was conducted under Ar (50 mL/min) by increasing the temperature up to 800 ℃ with a 10 ℃/min ramping rate. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, using a TA instrument TGA5500) was conducted on used catalysts (about 10 mg) from room temperature to 790 ℃ with a 10 ℃/min heating rate under air flow. 2.3 Experimental set-up and procedure As shown in Fig. 1 , the experimental set-up consists of a toluene generator, a catalytic reactor, and a detection unit. Toluene (Sigma–Aldrich, 99.99 %) was slowly diluted with high-purity air under the control of a micro syringe pump. The preheater and mixing tank ensured that the temperature of the mixed gas was consistent with the temperature of the catalyst in the reactor. The heated gas continued to pass through 0.2 g of catalyst at an inlet rate of 30 L/h, and the initial toluene concentration was stabilized at 250 ± 20 ppm. The temperature of the reactor steadily increased from room temperature with a 2 ℃/min heating rate until toluene was completely mineralized or the degradation rate reached the maximum. In this process, we used online gas chromatography to monitor and record the toluene and CO2 concentrations of the exhaust gas in real-time. Considering the fewer experimental sets available for model training, each test was performed thrice to ensure the adequacy of the prediction models. The catalytic activity of the prepared Ag/MnOx catalysts was distinguished by analyzing the T50 (CO2) and T50 (toluene) reaction temperatures (corresponding to 50 % CO2 yield and 50 % toluene conversion, respectively). 2.4 Computational details 2.4.1 Design of experiments A five-level CCD defined under RSM was employed as a design of experiment (DoE) to create an experiments matrix. Due to the various combinations of the independent variable levels, this experimental matrix was used to specify necessary tests in the experimental area under survey. Critical controllable conditions involved in the procedures of precipitation method including Ag loading (LAg), stirring time (ts), calcination temperature (Tc), and calcination time (tc) were selected as the four independent variables of CCD, while T50 (CO2) was taken as response factor. The region of each variable was determined based on relevant literature reports as well as our previous studies [6,9,14,45,46]. Five levels for each parameter were introduced. The coded (−2, −1, 0, +1, and +2) and real values of investigated factors are shown in Table 1 . By using the CCD experimental design, the original 5*5*5*5 trial runs were reduced to 30 representative experiments. In this proposed CCD matrix, 30 experiment sets consist of 6 repetitions (used to define the overall error of the experiments) at the center point, 8 axial points, and 16 factorial points were considered. 2.4.2 Neural network A multilayer perceptron neural network (MLPNN) was employed for tackling the correlation between the independent variables and the catalyst activity. As one of the most representative types of ANN, MLPNN has been widely applied for modeling and optimizing pollution controls and proved to be effective and easy to conduct [47–49]. It is well accepted that a well-trained MLPNN with an appropriate structure and training algorithm is capable of generating principles to simulate nonlinear input-output relationships. Normally, data samples are separated into three different subsets namely the training set, test set, and validation set with rations of 8:1:1 or 7:1.5:1.5 [50]. Given the small-scale data set of this study, the commonly used separation method can easily lead to overfitting. In this regard, leave one out cross validation (LOOCV), according to which only one data set was selected for test process and remaining data sets were used for training, was adopted to deal with this problem [51]. For instance, when the 1 st data sample was assigned to test subset, the rest data samples from 2nd to 30th were designated as the training subset, and this procedure was repeated for all thirty data sets. The topological structure of MLPNN and training parameters have significant impacts on predictive performance [52,53]. The input neuron numbers are in accord with the number of the determined preparation conditions including LAg, ts, Tc, and tc, while no systematic approaches exist for defining the optimal number of neurons in hidden layer(s). Commonly an MLPNN topology containing insufficient hidden layer neurons has difficulty in fully learning the data laws. However, excessive neurons can lead to over-fitting, resulting in the poor predictive capacity of the model. To determine the best numbers of hidden layers and hidden layer neurons, the trial and error observation was carried out. As a result, an optimal MLPNN model (illustrated in Fig. 2 ) with a 4:12:1 three-layer topology was obtained when employing Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm (trainglm) for training. The performance of the different models is mainly assessed by R2, a statistical parameter that indicates the relevance degree of the experimental and predicted values. The equation is given below: (1) R 2 = 1 - ∑ i = 1 N y p - y e 2 / ∑ i = 1 N y p - y e ¯ 2 where N is the number of output factor(s), y p is the predicted output, y e denotes the experimental output, and y e ¯ stands for the average values of the tests. The input factor importance representing the effect of each input variable on the output is defined as the following equation [54]: (2) S s = ∑ j n w s j u j k / ∑ i m w i j ∑ i m ∑ j n w i j u j k / ∑ i m w i j where S s denotes the importance of s th input parameter, w i j denotes the weight between the i th input and the j th neuron in the hidden layer, u j k denotes the weight that connects j th neuron in hidden layer with k th output neuron, m represents the number of input variables, n represents the number of hidden layer neurons, and k denotes the number of output parameters. 2.4.3 Neuro-genetic machine learning framework To search and screen potential Ag/MnOx catalysts and the corresponding preparation conditions, the proposed MLPNN was coupled with GA, a high-efficiency global optimization algorithm, to develop a neuro-genetic machine learning framework (ANN-GA). The flowchart of the proposed ANN-GA framework is given in Fig. 3 . Specifically, the GA creates a population of chromosomes randomly. Every single chromosome represents a virtual catalyst prepared within a limited range of conditions defined by the CCD experimental plan. Each chromosome contains four genes corresponding to the four investigated factors. Subsequently, by taking the lowest T50 (CO2) as the optimization objection, the feasibility of every chromosome is calculated based on its genes using the MLPNN, which acts as a fitness function. For each generation, the GA selects the chromosomes with relatively high fitness values from the current population as the parents. The population will be repeatedly updated by performing genetic operators (crossover and mutation) on these parents to produce offsprings for the next generation. As a result, the population evolves toward an optimal catalyst with the lowest T50 (CO2) over successive generations [49]. Herein, the optimization procedure was carried out by using the optimization toolbox of MATLAB 2016a software. The lower and upper bound of experimental factors defined by CCD are as follows: LAg = [0.5, 18.5], ts = [10, 90], Tc = [200, 600], and tc = [2,6]. Table 2 shows the setting options used for optimization. Other parameters retain default values or types. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The central composite design of Ag/MnOx The toluene abatement performance of each catalyst prepared according to the CCD experimental design matrix was investigated by analyzing the experimental T50 (CO2) and T50 (toluene). In the issue, the overall conducted testing results of 30 different catalysts given by CCD are shown in Table 3 . The test results exhibit that the 6 repetitions at the center point give the lower level of T50 (CO2) and T50 (toluene), revealing the preparation conditions corresponding to the lowest T50 (CO2) may be close to those of the central point. Besides, the T50 (CO2) of the 6 repetitions are very close, which indicates that the experimental error is acceptable. For simulating the nonlinear relationships between the four catalyst preparation conditions (LAg, ts, Tc, and tc) and toluene total oxidation efficiency (take T50 (CO2) as the indicator), we proposed RSM and MLPNN predictive models. The RSM model was obtained by inputting experimental outcomes into the experimental design matrix in Design-Expert software. On the other side, the MLPNN model was trained and verified by coding on the MATLAB software based on the experimental data set provided by CCD experimental design. 3.2 Screening of high-efficiency Ag/MnOx catalysts through RSM and ANN-GA 3.2.1 RSM modeling approach The RSM suggested a quadratic model that relates toluene abatement efficiency to the independent variables (Eq. 3). (3) T 50 C O 2 = 1 - 693.98 – 13.33 A – 1.85 B – 0.82 C – 86.93 D – 0.06 A B – 0.0001 A C + 0.04 A D + 0.0004 B C – 0.05 B D – 0.003 C D + 0.68 A 2 + 0.02 B 2 + 0.001 C 2 + 10.86 D 2 The T50 (CO2) is the response, and A, B, C, and D are the coded terms of Ag loading, stirring time, calcination temperature, and calcination time, respectively. The value and sign of each correlation phrase coefficient display the favorable and unfavorable effects of the response parameters. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed to evaluate the significance of the independent variables and the applicability of the developed quadratic model, as summarized in Table 4 . The model is statistically significant in the present work since the probability value (p-value) is below 0.0001. Fischer’s F-test (F-value) of 24.04 demonstrates the significance of the simulation. The low value of the coefficient of variance (C.V.) (2.66 %) confirms the good repeatability of the experiments. Despite the high value of the lack of fit (LOF) F-value, the correlation coefficient (R2) value of 0.9573 indicates that the regression model is relatively significant. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , the mutual effects of the four independent variables (LAg, ts, Tc, and tc) on the T50 (CO2) in the toluene total oxidation process were analyzed using the 3D response surface. It is seen from Fig. 4a–c that each preparation condition has an impact on the catalytic performance for toluene abatement, of which the LAg is the most significant factor. By increasing the LAg from 0.5–18.5 wt%, the value of T50 (CO2) first decreases from 306 ℃ to 220 ℃ and then rises to 260 ℃. The result implies that the optimum LAg may be in the range of 9.5 wt% to 14 wt%. The yield of CO2 reaches the maximum when the LAg is in the field of about 10 %–12 %. The increased catalytic activity related to LAg may be ascribed to the formation of defective Ag1.8Mn8O16 phase and the decrease of manganese oxidation state, which leads to more efficient interaction between silver and manganese species with toluene molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The results in Fig. 4d–f show that as the preparation conditions continuously change, the lowest point of T50 (CO2) roughly in the center of the response surface can be found. As a consequence, according to the analysis of the proposed RSM model, the lowest T50 (CO2) of 216.9 ℃ can be achieved for toluene abatement in catalytic oxidation at 11.9 %, 52.7 min, 410.9 ℃, and 4.1 h for LAg, ts, Tc, and tc, respectively. 3.2.2 ANN-GA framework modeling With the optimized ANN model, the results of the cross-validation process were obtained for thirty data samples by utilizing LOOCV. Fig. 5 integrates the comparative outcomes between the predicted value and experimental value, which suggests that the developed MLPNN model succeeds in learning the patterns between the four independent variables and T50 (CO2) despite the fewer data samples. Moreover, the proposed MLPNN model (R2 = 0.9872) outperforms the RSM model (R2 = 0.9573, as shown in Table 4) on predictive ability, which is in agreement with many previous studies [24,55–57]. For searching and screening potential Ag/MnOx catalysts, GA (applied to generate and optimize virtual catalysts for the predictive model) was coupled with a well-trained MLPNN (used to assess the fitness of virtual catalysts) to establish an ANN-GA machine learning framework. Creating virtual catalyst space and screening potential catalysts were accomplished by GA. The search behavior of the GA was illustrated in Fig. 6 . As the figure presents, the decrease in average and best fitness differences by the increase in generations exhibits good convergence of the GA optimization. The best and mean fitness value of every generation get together in 50 generations. Meanwhile, it is indicated that the utilized GA can screen the whole catalyst space without being trapped in local optimums. The above consequences suggest the good applicability of the ANN-GA framework modeling. The predicted values and experimental results of the optimum catalysts obtained through the proposed ANN-GA and RSM models (denoted Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM, respectively) contrast with the best-performed catalyst in the experimental plan of CCD (Run No.16, denoted Ag/MnOx-R16) are listed in Table 5 . One can see that the predicted T50 (CO2) of the Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM are well consistent with the experimental values. Besides, these predicted catalysts are validated to have preferable catalytic activity in toluene total oxidation than any of the synthesized catalysts among the matrix of CCD. Fig. 7 displays the relative significance of each input factor (the preparation conditions). The obtained result suggested that among the four investigated factors, including LAg, ts, Tc, and tc, the Ag loading contributes the most significant impact (38 %) on the catalyst performance. Considering to markedly affect the reducibility and stability of MnOx [20], the calcination temperature exhibits higher importance than stirring time and calcination time. To further investigate the effect of each preparation parameter on catalyst performance, grid search was implemented on the developed neural network, and the resultant T50 (CO2) versus values of each factor was plotted in Fig. 8 for the optimum catalyst Ag/MnOx-GA. In each plot, a grid search was performed on one factor, and the other three factors were fixed at their optimum values (seen in Table 5). It is clear from the simulation consequence in Fig. 8 that all these parameters have a volcano shape effect on catalytic activity, and knee point is found in each graph. Ag loading has the greatest effect on catalyst activity since different Ag doping can lead to the difference in the crystal phase of the prepared catalyst (discussed in 3.3.1). For calcination, two opposite effects have an impact on the catalyst performance. Firstly, the direct reduction of the metal precursor will promote the metal dispersion, so the calcination temperature should be high enough to ensure the metal precursor decomposition [58,59]. On the other hand, high temperature can facilitate the conversion of doped silver to low-valence silver species such as elemental silver and promote sintering with a loss of activity, too [60,61]. There exists a good agreement between the patterns presented by ANN-GA and the RSM analysis. The role of Ag loading on the structure, texture, active element valence, and redox capacity of the selected catalysts was discussed in Section 3.3. 3.3 Materials characterization 3.3.1 Structure and texture of Ag/MnOx The crystalline structures of the as-prepared materials were investigated by XRD. As displayed in Fig. 9 , the Ag/MnOx samples exhibit similar diffraction patterns, all of which can be well indexed with the tetragonal Ag1.8Mn8O16 phase (JCPDS No. 84-0873, space group I4/m(87)), tetragonal β-MnO2 phase (JCPDS No. 24-0735, space group P42/mnm(136)), cubic Mn2O3 phase (JCPDS No. 41-1442, space group Ia-3(206)) and cubic Ag2O phase (JCPDS No. 75-1532, space group Pn-3 m(224)) [12,13,17,62,63]. No additional characteristic peaks are assignable to the metallic silver, MnO, or other impurities [11]. The appearance of diffraction peaks with 2θ at 25.89°, 29.01°, 37.37°, 41.49°, 49.9°, and 69.9° indicates the presence of silver hollandite (Ag1.8Mn8O16), revealing that K+ ions are substituted by a portion of doped Ag in the channels of K-hollandite. Previous studies have reported that the hollandite structure can be maintained when introducing silver since the ionic radius of Ag+ (0.24 nm) is close to that of K+ (0.28 nm) so Ag+ can locate on the common faces (0, 0, 1/2) of the cubic cages formed by MnO6 octahedra [62,64]. Notably, significant peaks with 2θ at 32.85° and 38.12° are observed on the modified catalysts (both Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM) while these of Ag/MnOx-R16 are much weaker, suggesting that most of the silver species could exist in the form of Ag1.8Mn8O16 or the Ag2O may have poor dispersion over the Ag/MnOx-R16 surface. For these three samples characterized, Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM are prepared with relatively larger silver loadings (13.2 wt% and 11.9 wt%, respectively), and when the substitution of Ag+ for K+ reaches saturation, excess silver may be converted to Ag2O in the synthesis process. Table 6 summarizes the textural parameters of the different samples. The energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) analysis results of the overall synthesized samples are listed in Table S1, and the spectra of Ag/MnOx-GA, Ag/MnOx-RSM, and Ag/MnOx-R16 are presented in Fig. S1(A), (B), and (C), respectively. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and the Dp distribution plot are illustrated in Fig. S2, which unambiguously demonstrates that the micropores and the macropores are negligible and can be ruled out in toluene oxidation. The three investigated solids have BET surface areas of 84.4 (Ag/MnOx-GA), 68.9 (Ag/MnOx-RSM), and 40.2 m2 g−1 (Ag/MnOx-R16), respectively. The difference in specific surface areas results from the interaction of the four key variables in the catalyst preparation process, among which the silver loading related to the formation of Ag1.8Mn8O16 might play an important role in this case. It can be assumed that enhanced mesopores derived from the appropriate Ag substitution decrease the crystallite size and increase adsorption sites, which is favorable for toluene vapor decomposition [13,14]. The bulk contents of Ag, K, and Mn for all the catalysts were investigated by ICP-OES and presented in Table 6. The contents of the Ag element in the prepared samples are relatively consistent with the amounts added in the synthesis processes (with a loss of about 20 %). When the Ag/Mn molar ratio increases, the content of K is significantly lower, indicating a much more complete exchange between Ag+ ion and K+ ion [62]. The obtained results of ICP-OES could help explain the formation of Ag1.8Mn8O16 phase. SEM images are presented in Fig. S3 to show the morphology of the as-prepared materials. The graphs exhibit particles of pseudo-spherical morphology with an average size of 100 ∼ 200 nm and clusters of particles can be observed. The weights of different elements revealed by EDS analysis (Table S1) show a good agreement with the data of ICP-OES. According to the outcomes of scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image and energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDX) mapping (Fig. S4), the particles with cylindrical morphology in the Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM samples are probably Ag2O formed by the conversion of excess silver (I) under high-temperature calcination. Besides, the Raman spectra (presented in Fig. S5) of all the samples exhibit four major bands at 182, 386, 574, and 630 cm−1. The peaks of the deformation of Mn-O-Mn locate at 182 and 386 cm−1, while the peaks at 574 and 630 cm−1 can be ascribed to the Mn-O vibrations along and orthogonal to the direction of the MnO6 octahedral double chains, respectively. Peaks corresponding to silver are not observed, which is in accord with other reports [14,17]. 3.3.2 XPS surface analysis XPS data demonstrated in Table 7 were applied to determine the oxidation states of silver and manganese in the investigated samples. Fig. 10 presents the Mn 2p, Ag 3d, and O 1s XPS spectra of fresh and used Ag/MnOx samples. The Mn AOS was calculated by the following formula: (4) A O S = 8.956 − 1.126 Δ E s where Δ E s denotes the binding energy difference between the multiplet splitting of Mn 3 s [65]. The Mn 2p3/2 spectra of the Ag/MnOx catalysts are separated into two peaks around 641.7 and 642.5 eV, attributed to the simultaneous presence of Mn3+ and Mn4+ species [4]. It can be observed from the detailed information recorded in Table 7 that the ratios of Mn3+/Mn4+ for all the samples are in the intervals 2.7–3.3, which agrees with a mixture of Mn3+/4+ with Mn3+ as the predominant cation. Obviously, the ANN-GA and RSM optimization significantly impact the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ in the catalyst surface. Among the three catalysts derived from different preparation conditions, Ag/MnOx-GA exhibits the highest Mn3+/Mn4+ molar ratio (3.3) and the lowest Mn AOS (3.23). So it can be inferred that manganese (III) contributes to the improvement of catalytic performance because the surface Mn3+ content increment can increase the oxygen cavities numbers [66], demonstrating the enhanced oxygen vacancies in the Ag/MnOx-GA catalyst surface. As illustrated in Fig. 10b, the XPS binding energies of Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 for all Ag/MnOx samples are centered at the range of 367.6–367.7 eV and 373.6–373.7 eV. According to the relevant literature reports, the Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 peaks are located at 367.6 ± 0.2 and 373.6 ± 0.2 eV for Ag2O, 368.0 ± 0.2 and 374.0 ± 0.2 eV for Ag, respectively, and Ag 3d5/2 peak at 367.4 ± 0.2 eV can be assigned to AgO [11,67–69]. The Ag/MnOx-GA exhibits the highest silver content. The obtained Ag 3d binding energies are characterized as Ag+/Ag2O for all samples, which is in accord with the results of XRD patterns. Fig. 10c displays the XPS spectra of O 1s. Three peaks are observed at about 529.7, 531.5, and 533.0 eV, which can be ascribed to surface lattice oxygen (O2−, denoted as Olatt), surface adsorbed oxygen (O-, O2- or O2 2−, denoted as Oads), and adsorbed molecular water (denoted as Oamw), respectively. The optimization tools (ANN-GA and RSM) significantly enhance the proportion of Oads by regulating the LAg, ts, Tc, and tc. As a consequence, the ratio of Oads/Olatt in the three samples follows the order of Ag/MnOx-GA＞Ag/MnOx-RSM＞Ag/MnOx-R16, agreeing with the above inference (derived from Mn 2p3/2 spectra) that the enhanced surface oxygen vacancies caused by Mn (III) increase could explain the high activity of Ag/MnOx-GA. Previous studies have reported that Oads is concerned with the presence of oxygen vacancies [11]. These regenerable oxygen vacancies play a pivotal part in gaseous oxygen adsorption [12]. 3.3.3 H2-TPR and O2-TPD studies H2-TPR and O2-TPD experiments were conducted to probe into the redox capacities of Ag/MnOx-GA, Ag/MnOx-RSM, and Ag/MnOx-R16, as illustrated in Fig. 11 . It is worth noting that the TCD traces relative to Ag/MnOx catalysts are not in good accordance with the reported results of Ag-hollandite [17,62] or cryptomelane [12,14,18] since the synthesized materials are mixtures of Ag1.8Mn8O16, Mn2O3, MnO2, and Ag2O. It can be observed that the Ag/MnOx-R16 shows four reduction peaks at 176, 216, 253, and 360 °C, respectively. The lowest temperature reduction process corresponds to the reduction of Ag+ to Ag° (Ag2O → Ag) [17,18,63]. The three other ones are in line with the successive decrease in MnO2 → Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 → MnO [45,70]. Similar reduction property can be observed for Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM, which also exhibit four reduction peaks. Still, all of them shift to lower temperatures, indicating the reducibility decreases in the order of Ag/MnOx-GA > Ag/MnOx-RSM > Ag/MnOx-R16. This order is in good agreement with the variation in their activities for toluene abatement, affirming that the proposed ANN-GA framework can be employed to discover optimum catalysts with promoted reducibility by searching virtual catalyst space. The corresponding H2 consumptions of the different samples in the reduction process are summarized in Table 6. The H2 consumptions of Ag/MnOx-GA, Ag/MnOx-RSM, and Ag/MnOx-R16 on a per Ag mol basis are 5.79, 6.74, and 8.33 mol/mol Ag, respectively. According to the H2-uptake and the corresponding Mn content analyzed by ICP-OES, the Mn AOS (assuming MnO as the final product) for Ag/MnOx-GA, Ag/MnOx-RSM, and Ag/MnOx-R16 are calculated to be 3.25, 3.29, and 3.35 [70], respectively, which are in agreement with the values of 3.23, 3.29 and 3.33 confirmed by XPS analysis. The fact that the H2 consumption appears not to related with surface area could be attributed to the difference in Mn AOS, since the sample Ag/MnOx-R16 may contain more high-valence manganese oxide species such as MnO2. O2-TPD experiments were carried out to further elucidate the oxygen species activity in Ag/MnOx catalysts. As shown in Fig. 11b, four desorption peaks are observed in the TPD profile of every sample. The signal viewed in temperature regions of 532–543 °C (peak I) is ascribed to the desorption of lattice oxygen from MnO2 and Ag1.8Mn8O16 to form Mn2O3, while the strong peaks at about 560 °C (peak II) and 705 °C (peak IV) correspond to the desorption of lattice oxygen of Mn2O3 to produce Mn3O4 and MnO, respectively [63,71,72]. The weak peak in the range of 613–623 °C (peak III) can be attributed to oxygen desorption from silver subsurface [72]. No obvious variation can be observed in the last desorption peak. However, the other three desorption peaks in optimized catalysts gradually shift to higher temperatures when comparing to that of Ag/MnOx-R16. Meanwhile, the peak III in Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM become stronger, which may be caused by the formation of stable Ag1.8Mn8O16. Previous studies have indicated that the capacity for oxygen activation could be enhanced when the catalysts were characterized with larger peaks intensities and lower oxygen desorption temperatures [73]. The obtained results clarify that the optimized catalysts, especially Ag/MnOx-GA, exhibited preferable reducibility and oxygen species activity, which is in accordance with the performance for total oxidation of toluene. 3.4 Performance of modified catalysts for toluene total oxidation The catalytic performance as a function of temperature over Ag/MnOx-GA, Ag/MnOx-RSM, and Ag/MnOx-R16 catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 12 . The toluene conversion rates gradually increase to about 5% as temperature increases in the range of 50–130 ℃. Simultaneously, obvious enhancements in CO2 yields are not observed, which could be ascribed to the adsorption of toluene vapor on the catalyst surface. The curves of toluene conversion rates with temperature are highly consistent with the curves of CO2 yields with temperature, suggesting a low by-product yield and a relatively high CO2 selectivity. The fact that GC–MS detects no obvious peaks of carbon monoxide, benzoic acid, benzaldehyde, and other by-products probably produced by the incomplete oxidation of toluene during the reaction also provides evidence for the above inference. Comparing to Ag/MnOx-RSM and Ag/MnOx-R16, Ag/MnOx-GA exhibits a higher activity for toluene total oxidation with the lowest T50 (toluene) and T50 (CO2) (204 and 206 ℃, respectively). To confirm whether the impurities (Ag2O and β-MnO2) are involved in the catalytic oxidation process, we tested the reactivity of pure-phase Ag2O and β-MnO2 solids. As shown in Fig. S6, Ag2O have no activity for toluene abatement below 400 ℃. For β-MnO2, effective toluene removal can be observed when the temperature rises above 270 ℃. Consequently, these impurities have a limited influence on catalyst performance as the prepared materials exhibit activity for toluene oxidation at temperatures below 200 ℃. Fig. 13 illustrates toluene conversion (a) and CO2 yield (b) as a function of time on stream (24 h) for the as-prepared materials. In the plot of toluene conversion, Ag/MnOx-GA and Ag/MnOx-RSM catalysts are relatively high stable and durable with a slight decline in the first 4 h from 50 % to 48 % for Ag/MnOx-GA and 30 % to 25 % for Ag/MnOx-RSM, respectively. However, significant deactivation can be observed over Ag/MnOx-R16 catalyst during this 4 h, at which 15 % of toluene conversion is noted. Besides, the trends of CO2 yield over these three solids are similar to that of toluene conversion, revealing the fairly high CO2 selectivity of the synthesized catalysts. To further investigate the thermal stability of the catalysts, the TGA analysis was performed under dry air in the temperature regions of 50–790 °C on the dried catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 14 , all the TGA profiles show a similar small weight loss at temperatures up to 200 °C, corresponding to the removal of physically adsorbed and chemisorbed water [74–76]. Subsequently, when the temperature exceeds 200 °C, the Ag/MnOx-GA sample steadily loses mass until approximately 500 °C, after which a weight loss (around 1.5 wt%) that possibly due to the crystallization of the material and the decomposition of Ag2O occurs [45]. However, a relatively distinct weight gain (around 0.5–1 wt%) can be observed in TG plots of both Ag/MnOx-RSM and Ag/MnOx-R16 in the temperature range of 450–700 °C, which is ascribed to the oxidization of Mn3O4 phase to produce Mn2O3 [77]. Upon increasing the temperature, all the three plots exhibit significant weight loss due to a further oxygen release of the transformation to Mn3O4 [78,79]. These obtained results make it clear that the total weight loss of all the three catalysts in the temperature-rise period (50–400 °C) of toluene catalytic oxidation tests can be approximately 1 wt%, suggesting that there is almost no carbon deposition on the material surface, which is in agreement with the stability analysis outcome. 4 Conclusions All in all, conclusions can be summarized as the following: The presented ANN-GA machine learning framework succeeded in predicting potential high-efficiency Ag/MnOx catalyst, which exhibited preferable activity and stability in terms of toluene total oxidation and outperformed the RSM model on global optimization capability. The reduction of 14℃ on the T50 (CO2) demonstrated the feasibility of this optimizing strategy. The doping silver concentration and calcination temperature were the two most significant precipitation conditions on the catalytic performance according to the relative significance analysis. The formation of Ag1.8Mn8O16 contributed to the promotion of the catalytic activity. The appropriate silver substitution was assumed to enhance mesopores, leading to a decrease of crystallite size and the increase of adsorption sites. The lowest Mn AOS (3.25) and the highest Oads/Olatt ratio of the optimum catalyst suggested the Mn (III) increase enhanced the surface oxygen vacancies, contributing to toluene abatement. The improvement of catalyst performance was attributed to the combination of all the involved preparation conditions. It makes sense to establish the mapping relationship between these multi-parameters and catalytic reactivity with the aid of nonlinear simulation techniques to accelerate the optimization of catalyst preparation. coredata.dc:description: A neuro-genetic machine learning framework (ANN-GA) was employed to optimize and predict the optimum preparation parameters for the precipitation synthesis of high-efficiency silver-doped manganese oxides (Ag/MnOx) for toluene total oxidation. The preparation conditions of Ag/MnOx for maximum CO2 yield were predicted to be at 13.2 wt% of silver loading, 41.5 min of stirring time, 461 ℃ of calcination temperature, and 4.3 h of calcination time. The resulting Ag/MnOx-GA catalyst achieved the lowest T50 (CO2) of 206 ℃ comparing to the catalyst suggested by the response surface methodology (RSM) (214 ℃) and synthesized catalyst Ag/MnOx-R16 (220 ℃). The obtained relative importance of each factor involved in the preparation process revealed that all of the parameters should be taken into account, among which the silver loading had the most significant impact on the catalytic reactivity. The synthesized materials were characterized by ICP-OES, SEM/EDS, BET, Raman, XRD, XPS, TGA, H2-TPR, and O2-TPD. The results indicated that the Ag/MnOx-GA exhibited the largest surface area (84.4), the lowest average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn (3.25), the best redox capacity, and the highest ratios of Oads/Olatt (0.75). These consequences provided evidence that the toluene total oxidation was more likely to occur on the surface of Ag/MnOx-GA at a relatively lower temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Neuro-genetic machine learning framework accelerates the optimization of Ag/MnOx catalyst for total oxidation of toluene
